subject: Philosophy
title: The Good Life
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Good Life.

hook.text: Aristotle had a word for the good life: eudaimonia. It meant flourishing, not just feeling happy.

buildup.text: He argued happiness isn't pleasure. It's the result of living virtuously and fulfilling your potential.

discovery.text: Epicurus disagreed. The good life is simple: avoid pain, enjoy modest pleasures, keep good friends.

twist.text: The Stoics took a harder line. Virtue alone is enough â€” even suffering can't ruin the good life.

climax.text: Three schools, three answers. Centuries later, we still can't agree on what it means.

punchline.text: Everyone wants the good life. No one agrees what it is.

quiz.question: What did Aristotle call the good life?
